name: Judge
description: Investigator The world is evil, and secrets and rituals occur behind closed doors in the guise of nightfall within each city or village. You have set your quest to rid this evil by any means necessary. The means justify the end, and violence is but a mere tool of punishment handed out to the guilty. You are both the judge and executioner of those who have taken to the dark arts. Your eyes have witnessed hundreds of suspected magic users burned at a stake and tortured by pitiless investigators. The truth shall reveal itself through pain and blood, but how many of those you convicted were genuinely innocent or completely guilty? Obscured by the puritanical education and oath you have sworn to, you now begin to see the world's truth. For all the evil you have destroyed, it has not changed the course of humankind. Every human has both good and evil within them. It is time to change your course and discover the true nature of evil and if you have sentenced those who have partaken in it. Level P. Bonus Features Spells Known Cantrips Known 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 1st +2 - - - - - - - - 2nd +2 Spellcasting 2 2 2 - - - - 3rd +2 Divine Protection, Book of Sins, Addenda I, Deep knowledge 3 3 3 - - - - 4th +2 Ability Score Improvement 5 4 3 - - - - 5th +3 - 6 4 4 2 - - - 6th +3 Zealous Nature, Book of Sins, Addenda II 7 4 4 3 - - - 7th +3 Book of Sins, Extension 8 4 4 3 - - - 8th +3 Ability Score Improvement 9 4 4 3 - - - 9th +4 Book of Sins, Extension 10 4 4 3 2 - - 10th +4 Book of Sins, Addenda III 11 5 4 3 2 - - 11th +4 Book of Sins, Extension 12 5 4 3 3 - - 12th +4 Ability Score Improvement 12 5 4 3 3 - - 13th +5 Book of Sins, Addenda IV 13 5 4 3 3 1 - 14th +5 Arcana Inquisitionis 13 5 4 3 3 1 - 15th +5 Book of Sins, Extension 14 5 4 3 3 2 - 16th +5 Ability Score Improvement 14 5 4 3 3 2 - 17th +6 Book of Sins, Extension 15 5 4 3 3 3 1 18th +6 Arcana Inquisitionis, Addenda 15 5 4 3 3 3 1 19th +6 Ability Score Improvement 15 5 4 3 3 3 2 20th +6 Ultimus Justiciar 15 6 4 3 3 3 2 Class Features Hit Points Hit Dice: 1d8 Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per Judge level after 1st Proficiencies Armor: Light Armor Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons Tools: Calligrapher's supplies Saving Throws: Wisdom, Charisma Skills: Investigation, plus choose two between Arcana, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, Persuasion and Religion Equipment You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background: (a) a handaxe of Purification and a hand crossbow or (b) a Hand crossbow of Purification and any light weapon A studded leather armor and 20 crossbow bolts Book of Sins and Gavel (a) a scholar's pack or (b) an explorer's pack Level 1 Enemies of the Inquisition: you hunt down dark sorcerers and the foul creatures they associate with. Certain class features will have additional effects against creatures in this list: Spellcasters: for the purpose of this class’s features and spells, a Spellcaster is defined as any creature that can cast Spells or that has at least one melee or ranged spell attack on its stat block. Fiends, undeads and monstrosities. Weapon of Purification: this weapon (traditionally a Handaxe or a Hand Crossbow) has been anointed with sacred oils and inscribed with mystical sigils. You can use your Intelligence modifier for attack and damage rolls with these weapons, instead of the Strength or Dexterity one, as long as they are Light weapons. Judgment: When you wield at least one Weapon of Purification, you can attempt to pass Judgment on a creature within 30ft of you. As part of the Attack action against a creature, make an Investigation skill check with a DC equal to 5 + the creature’s CR (rounded up). You have advantage on this check if you are targeting an Enemy of the Inquisition. Certitude: If you succeed, you recognize the creature’s crimes. You are armed with an encyclopedic knowledge of the Inquisitorial Records and you recall how to exploit their vices and weaknesses. For the next minute, you gain the benefits of the spell Hunter’s Mark against this creature; you don’t need to maintain concentration on it and you can’t move it to another creature if this one dies. Doubt: If you fail, your doubts make you falter - maybe you are unsure about the creature’s nature, or you fail to recall the prescribed methods to dispatch them. Your attacks against that creature have disadvantage until the start of your next turn. Practice makes perfect: Select the place where you forged your path as an apprentice: Attorney of the Inquisition Courts When the Inquisitorial Courts demand justice, the Judge wields it using their favorite weapon, The Gavel. There is magic within households, behind churches, and in dark alleys. The Judge must locate this black magic and destroy its user. Gavel: As bonus action you can use your Gavel to smite an enemy that can see it within 15 ft of you. The target must succeed on a DEX SAVE or take 1d6 Radiant damage and be blinded until the end of your next turn. Examiner: You gain proficiency in Intimidation. If you already have proficiency with that skill, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any Intimidation check you make. This feature does not stack with other bonuses that double your proficiency bonus for this skill. Inquisition Inspector Behind the lavish trials and public sermons lies the true work of a Judge of the Inquisition Courts. The art of interrogating suspected heretics is a skill that not many have. Distinguishing falsehoods is one challenge, but to extract the truth is entirely different. Facing the Book: As bonus action you present your Book of Sins to sear the flesh of an enemy that can see it within 15 ft of you. The target must succeed on a DEX SAVE or lose its resistance and/or immunity to fire damage until the end of your next turn. The creature then takes 1d6 Fire Damage. Investigator: You gain proficiency in Insight. If you already have proficiency with that skill, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any Insight check you make. This feature does not stack with other bonuses that double your proficiency bonus for this skill. Level 2 Spellcasting By the time you reach 2nd level, you have learned to use the tools of your enemies to hunt them down. Spell Slots The Judge of Absolution table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your Judge of Absolution spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest. For example, if you know the 1st-level spell Alarm and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast Alarm using either slot. Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the Judge of Absolution spell list. The Spells Known column of the Judge of Absolution table shows when you learn more Judge of Absolution spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 5th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level. Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the Judge of Absolution spells you know and replace it with another spell from the Judge of Absolution spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots. Spellcasting Ability Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Judge of Absolution spells, since your magic draws on your attunement to nature. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a Judge of Absolution spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one. Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier Spellcasting Focus and Somatic Components At 2nd level, you can use one of your Weapon of Purifications as a focus to cast spells that require a Material component. You can cast spells that require a Somatic component from the Judge of Absolution spell lists even if you have both hands occupied, as long as both hands are holding a Weapon of Purification. Urban combatant: when you are wearing light armor or no armor and are wielding a Weapon of Purification in each hand, you can add your Intelligence modifier to your AC. No matter what armor you wear, as long as you are wielding a Weapon of Purification in each hand, you gain the following bonus: when you take the Attack action and make an attack with a Light weapon, you can use a bonus action to attack with a hand crossbow you are holding. Being within 5 ft. of an hostile creature doesn’t impose disadvantage on your attacks with hand crossbows. Level 3 Rituals of Purification: you have learned the secrets required to create a Weapon of Purification. You hold the weapon in your hand(s) and perform a ritual that lasts 1 hour (that can be completed during a Short Rest); after that, the weapon gains all the benefits of a Weapon of Purification on top of its original ones. You can never have more than 2 Weapons of Purifications at the same time. Divine Protection: The Gods help those who help themselves. You learn the Shield spell; this spell doesn’t count against the total spells you can know. Book of Sins, Addenda I: You enhance your Inquisition manual with more tools. Choose one: Purge: You learn the Firebolt cantrip. This cantrip doesn’t count against the total of spells you can know. Sphere of Contempt: You gain a +1 bonus to your AC against attacks from a creature that is an Enemy of the Inquisition. Barrier of Purity: You learn the Mage Armor spell. This spell doesn’t count against the total of spells you can know. Torch of Truth: As an Action, you can cause your Weapon of Purification to shed bright light in a 60 ft radius for 1 hour whenever you wield it. While inside this radius, you have advantage on Perception checks that rely on sight and you can’t be surprised by Enemies of the Inquisition. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. Deep knowledge: you know 1 additional spell from the Judge of Absolution List. Tools of the Inquisition: Enemies of the Inquisition have disadvantage on the saves to avoid the effects of your Gavel or Facing the Book features. New Evidence: as a Reaction when you fail to pass Judgment against a creature, you can reroll one of the dice from the Investigation check, potentially causing the skill check to succeed. Shroud of Conviction: when you reduce an Enemy of Inquisition to 0 hit points, you gain temporary hit points equal to your level of Judge of Absolution + your Intelligence modifier. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Level 4 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 5 Extra Attack: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Level 6 Zealous Nature: You gain the ability to cast the Detect Evil and Good spell at will. Book of Sins, Addenda II: you further enhance your Inquisition manual with more tools. Choose one of these (or one from the previous Addenda lists): Tortured Soul: As an action, you can expend a Spell slot to choose a creature that you have successfully passed Judgment upon within 30 ft of you. The creature must succeed on a WIS SAVE or become Incapacitated until the start of your next turn. They also suffer 1d6 Radiant damage per spell level slot. On a successful save, they still receive the Radiant damage but are not Incapacitated. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Improved Gavel: increases the damage from your Gavel feature to 2d6 radiant damage. Improved Facing the Book: increases the damage from your Facing the Book feature to 2d6 fire damage. Sentenced to the Flames: As an Action, you can expend a Spell slot to choose a creature that you have successfully passed Judgment upon within 30 ft of you. The creature ignites, radiating flames in a 15ft radius around itself. Every hostile creature within radius (including the creature) must succeed on a CON SAVE or take 2d4 fire damage per spell level slot (or half as much on a successful save). Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Sacrata: You gain resistance to fire damage. Level 7 Book of Sins, Extension: you can choose another feature from one of the Book of Sins Addenda available to you. Keen Eye: Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any Investigation check you make. This feature does not stack with other bonuses that double your proficiency bonus for this skill. Level 8 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 9 Book of Sins, Extension: you can choose another feature from one of the Book of Sins Addenda available to you. Level 10 Book of Sins, Addenda III: you further enhance your Inquisition manual with more tools. Choose one of these (or one from the previous Addenda lists): Gavel of Light: when you use your Gavel feature against an Enemy of the Inquisition, you benefit from the effects of half cover against their attacks until the end of your next turn. Soulfire: when you use your Facing the Book feature against an Enemy of the Inquisition, on a failed save they become vulnerable to fire damage until the end of your next turn. Edictum Infernus: As an Action, you can expend a Spell slot to choose a creature that you have successfully passed Judgment upon within 30ft of you. The creature must succeed on a WIS SAVE or become visibly branded with a Mark of Purification until the start of your next turn. While it is marked, you control the creature’s movement during its turn; any time the marked creature moves within 5 ft of another hostile creature, they both receive 1d4 Radiant damage per spell level slot. The effect can only trigger once per other hostile creature. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Lex Talionis: As a reaction when one of your allies that you can see within 15ft is about to suffer damage from an attack, you can choose an enemy that you can see within 15ft. The enemy also suffers the damage. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Purging Barrage: As an Action, you can expend a Spell slot to choose a hostile creature that you have successfully passed Judgment upon within 30ft of you. The creature must succeed on a DEX SAVE or be pierced by smoldering nails, taking 1d6 Fire damage per spell level slot (or half as much on a successful save). If the save is failed, the creature is also affected by Dispel Magic, except the level of effects dispelled is based on the spell slot used. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Level 11 Book of Sins, Extension: you can choose another feature from one of the Book of Sins Addenda available to you. Tribunal of Faith: when you pass Judgment, you can choose to target any number of creatures within range instead of just one. In this case, make a single Investigation check with a DC based on the highest CR creature among the ones selected. All of them have to be Enemies of the Inquisition to roll with advantage. The effects of the Judgment are applied to every enemy targeted. Level 12 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 13 Book of Sins, Addenda IV: you further enhance your Inquisition manual with more tools. Choose one of these (or one from the previous Addenda lists): Voice of Sententia: As an Action, you can expend a Spell slot to choose a creature that you have successfully passed Judgment upon within 30ft of you. The creature must succeed on a WIS SAVE or become Stunned until the start of your next turn. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can choose to target an additional creature. Each creature must be within 5ft of the original one. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Mea Culpa: You gain the ability to learn from your mistakes, cleansing yourself and restoring your sense of justice. As a bonus action, you regain hit points equal to Judge of Absolution level plus your Intelligence modifier and remove any curses, diseases, or poisons affecting you. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. Justiciars Chains: As an Action, you can expend a Spell slot to choose a creature that you have successfully passed Judgment upon within 30ft of you. The creature must succeed on an INT SAVE or become chained. While they are chained, they are restrained and incapacitated. The effect lasts for 1 round per spell level, but the chained creature can choose to become repentant at the start of each of its turns. In that case, the creature is no longer chained, but the Judge of Absolution controls the creature’s action for that turn, then the effect ends. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Deeper knowledge: you know 2 additional spells from the Judge of Absolution List. Level 14 Arcana Inquisitionis: Choose two spells from any other class, A spell you choose must be of a level you can cast, as shown on the Judge of Absolution table, or a cantrip. The chosen spells count as Judge of Absolution spells for you, are always prepared and don't count against the total of spells you can prepare. Level 15 Book of Sins, Extension: you can choose another feature from one of the Book of Sins Addenda available to you. Level 16 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 17 Book of Sins, Extension: you can choose another feature from one of the Book of Sins Addenda available to you. Level 18 Arcana Inquisitionis, Addenda: Choose two spells from any other class, A spell you choose must be of a level you can cast, as shown on the Judge of Absolution table, or a cantrip. The chosen spells count as Judge of Absolution spells for you, are always prepared and don't count against the total of spells you can prepare. Level 19 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 20 ULTIMUS JUSTICIAR You transform into the maximum Judge that can sentence and carry out punishments to those who oppose the path of light. You gain the following abilities: Golden Gavel: When you use your Reaction to use the Gavel feature, you gain another reaction. Searing Sins: When you use your Reaction to use the Facing the Book feature, you gain another reaction. Absentia: You can use a bonus action to teleport to an unoccupied point that you can see within 60 ft. Auto-Da-Fe: As an Action, you can choose a creature that you have successfully passed Judgment upon within 30ft of you. The creature must succeed on a CON SAVE or be consumed by flames, suffering half of its maximum HP in fire damage. Judge of Absolution Spells

name: Light Bringer
description: Born in Light In a world of chaos, you cast a bright light over the dark path of evil. To be darkness, Light must exist. You learned the art of combat at an early age. You were raised in a convent of the Sisters of Everlasting Light and became proficient in combat and fabricating the Magic of Light from a young age. The Sisters of the monastery would claim you were molded from the Light, forged for the good of this world and raised by the holy word. You are an experiment of good, unleashed on the earth to rid it of its sins. Your only quest is to vanquish evil from this world. To bring it to its knees and plead for atonement. You do not seek violence or conflict but will act swiftly within it. Violence begets violence, and you use your powers to avert it whenever possible. You have only known good in your life; evil is the opposite of everything you breathe. You have no knowledge about romantic love or friendship and were raised to fight and rid the sins of the world; it is the curse that you have been handed. You have been raised in this glass shell, yet you must break it to discover who you are and what you can become. To do so, you must discover your past. Who left you at the convent, who took away your will and choice to be decided by others, albeit holy people? You must learn from the Sisters where you were raised and your origins. If you have any family, are they alive? Although you cannot change your past, you can forge your future. Level Proficiency Max Dim Value Features 1st +2 8 Inner Light, Sword of Light, Ray of Healing 2nd +2 Lux Strike, Born in Light 3rd +2 Rite of Sisterhood, Inner Strength 4th +2 Ability Score Improvement 5th +3 12 Extra Attack, Devout Acolyte 6th +3 Blazing Lunge, Source of Light 7th +3 Battle Meditation, Circle of Protection 8th +3 Ability Score Improvement 9th +4 16 Everlasting Blessing, Enhanced Ray of Healing 10th +4 Silent Vow, Sworn Warrior 11th +4 Spinning Light Strike, Enhanced Circle of Protection 12th +4 Ability Score Improvement 13th +5 20 Mirror of Light, Holy Body 14th +5 Lightning Storm 15th +5 Enhanced Sword of Light, Enhanced Everlasting Blessing 16th +5 Ability Score Improvement 17th +6 24 Eyes of Fury, Enhanced Silent Vow 18th +6 Radiant Power 19th +6 Ability Score Improvement 20th +6 Vessel of Light Class Features Hit Points Hit Dice: 1d10 Hit Points at 1st Level: 1d10 + your Constitution modifier Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per Light Bringer level after 1st Proficiencies Armor: All armor, Shields Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons Tools: None Saving Throws: Wisdom, Constitution Skills: Choose two from Athletics, Acrobatics, History, Insight, Medicine, Performance and Religion Equipment You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background: (a) chain mail and a holy symbol or (b) studded leather armor and a holy symbol (a) a martial weapon and a shield or (b) two martial weapons (a) a priest's pack or (b) an explorer's pack Level 1 Inner Light: you are gifted with a mighty innate spiritual force. Certain features will Dim your Light, making you temporarily weaker; but you can Rekindle your Light to obtain powerful effects - light shines brightest in the dark. Dim Value: You have a Dim Value that starts at 0 and represents your Inner Light fading. Your Dim Value can never be more than four times your Proficiency bonus. If at any point your current hit points are at or below this value, you immediately drop to 0 hit points and your Dim value is set to 0. Dim your Light: Every time a feature Dims your Light, you increase your Dim Value by an amount chosen by you, up to your Proficiency bonus. You can use features that Dim your Light without increasing your Dim Value if you want to. Rekindle your Light: when a feature Rekindles your Light, you gain temporary hit points equal to your Dim Value; you also gain certain benefits based on your current Dim Value, depending on the feature. Finally, your Dim Value is set to 0. Sword of Light: This feature will Dim your Light. As a Bonus Action when you take the Attack action against an hostile creature, you can ignite your weapon with the energy of the God of Light. For the next 1 minute, you can use your Wisdom modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls when making a melee weapon attack. For the same duration, your attacks also inflict extra lighting damage equal to your proficiency bonus. If you use this feature again before the effect has ended, the duration is refreshed. Ray of Healing: This feature will Rekindle your Light. As a bonus action you can use your holy powers to heal an ally (including yourself) that you can see within 30 ft of you. The ally regains hit points equal to 1d8 + your Dim Value. A creature can't regain hit points from this feature again until it has finished a short or long rest. Level 2 Lux Strike: This feature will Dim your Light. You can spend your Inner Light to empower your attacks. When you hit an hostile creature with a melee weapon attack, you can choose to Dim your Light; this attack deals extra radiant damage equal to the increase in your Dim Value. Born in Light: This feature will Rekindle your Light. While your Dim Value is at its maximum value, you can be renewed in the Light when your current hit points go below your Dim Value, but don’t reach 0. In this case, your current hit points are set to half your maximum hit points instead of 0, then you Rekindle your Light. You can use this feature a number of times each day equal to half your proficiency bonus, but no more than once per short rest. Level 3 Rite of Sisterhood: This feature will Rekindle your Light. As a reaction when you miss with an attack, you enter a deep trance connecting with the bond of the Convent of Everlasting Light. When you do so, you gain a pool of blessings equal to your Dim Value. You can distribute these blessings however you choose between one or more creatures (you included) within 30 ft of you. For each blessing received, that creature gains advantage on one attack or save they make before the end of their next turn. Inner Strength: You gain proficiency in Strength saving throws. You gain advantage on Strength skill checks. Level 4 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 5 Extra Attack: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Devout Acolyte: You gain proficiency in Religion. If you already have proficiency with that skill, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any Religion check you make. This feature does not stack with other bonuses that double your proficiency bonus for this skill. Level 6 Blazing Lunge: This feature will Dim your Light. When you take the Attack action, you can replace one of your attacks with this feature. You propel yourself through the ether and land with a burst of light. Choose an unoccupied space that you can see within 30ft and that is within 5ft of at least one hostile creature; teleport to that point. Every enemy within 5ft of your new location must make a CHA SAVE with a DC equal to (8 + your Wisdom modifier + your proficiency bonus) or become blinded until the start of your next turn. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Source of Light: This feature will Rekindle your Light. As a Bonus Action, you can cause a spark of holy energy in a radius of 10 ft around you. Every enemy in that area suffers lightning damage equal to your Dim Value and they have disadvantage on the next attack they make before the start of your next turn. Level 7 Battle Meditation: You gain resistance to Radiant damage. Also, when you roll initiative you can choose to Dim your Light once. Circle of Protection: This feature will Dim your Light. You can cast Protection from Evil and Good without requiring components or a spell slot as a bonus action. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. Level 8 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 9 Everlasting Blessing: This feature will Rekindle your Light. As an action you can cast Aid without requiring components or a spell slot. Each target’s hit point maximum and current hit points increase by an amount equal to 5 or your Dim Value until the next dawn. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. Enhanced Ray of Healing: When you use your Ray of Healing feature, you can target an additional ally within range. Level 10 Silent Vow: As a reaction when you are about to become frightened, you enter a trance and cannot speak for a duration of ten minutes. During this time you are immune to being Frightened. Sworn Warrior: This feature will Dim your Light. As a bonus action, choose up to three fiends or undead enemies that you can see within 30 ft. of you. Dim your Light once for each enemy you chose. For the next minute, when you hit one of these enemies with an attack they lose all their damage resistances and damage immunities until the end of your next turn. You can’t target the same enemy again until you Rekindle your Light. Level 11 Spinning Light Strike: This feature will Rekindle your Light. When you take the Attack action, you can replace one of your attacks with this feature. Roll a number of d8s equal to a third of your Dim Value. Every enemy within 5 ft of you must make a DEX SAVE with a DC equal to (8 + your Wisdom modifier + your proficiency bonus) or suffer lightning damage equal to the amount rolled (or half as much on a successful save). You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier each day. Enhanced Circle of Protection: You can use your Circle of Protection feature again after you have finished a short or long rest. Level 12 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 13 Mirror of Light: This feature will Dim your Light. You can use this feature as a reaction when you are making a saving throw against an effect caused by an hostile creature that is only targeting you. The hostile creature must immediately make a save as if it had targeted itself as well with the same effect. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Holy Body: You gain resistance to Necrotic damage. Level 14 Lightning Storm: This feature will Rekindle your Light. As an action, you can cast Call Lightning without requiring components or a spell slot. You cast this spell as the equivalent of a 5th level slot; the first strike also deals additional lightning damage equal to your Dim Value. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. Level 15 Enhanced Sword of Light: when you use your Sword of Light feature, you inflict extra damage equal to double your proficiency bonus. Enhanced Everlasting Blessing: when you use your Everlasting Blessing feature, you can instead cast Heroes' Feast without requiring components or a spell slot. You can target a number of creatures equal to your Dim Value. Level 16 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 17 Eyes of Fury: This feature will Dim your Light. As a bonus action, you can target an enemy within 30 ft of you that can see you and that you can see. The enemy becomes restrained until the start of your next turn unless they are immune to being Frightened; fiends and undeads cannot benefit from any immunity to being Frightened against this feature. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Enhanced Silent Vow: when you use your Silent Vow feature you also become immune to being Charmed, Paralyzed and Stunned. Level 18 Radiant Power: As a Reaction when you take radiant damage from an hostile creature’s attacks or effects, you take no damage and instead regain a number of hit points equal to the radiant damage dealt. Level 19 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 20 Vessel of Light You become the highest source of light for the Gods and channel their power in the ether. You gain the following abilities: Heavenly Strike: you can use your Lightning Storm ability (and the Call Lightning effect on following turns) as a bonus action. Fury of the Gods: Any hostile aberration, elemental, fey, fiend, and undead that sees you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become frightened by you until the end of their next turn. Creatures immune to fear can’t benefit from said immunity against this feature. If a creature's saving throw is successful, the creature is immune to this feature for the next 24 hours. Soul Light: during your turn, you can turn your body into pure light. Until you end this effect, you gain a flight speed (hover) equal to your movement speed and you can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. You take 5 (1d10) force damage if you end your turn inside an object.

name: Magi
description: Witchcraft Magic flows through your veins as it has through those of your ancestors. Your family lineage extends far back in time and has always been intertwined with magic. Troubled times forced you to shelter your powers for most of your life, yet now you understand that you cannot fight them, and you must fully embrace that ethereal link that binds your soul. Unearthing your true potential and the latent powers within you will entail a long journey of discovery. In your quest, you will also face those who oppose using magic and persecute it because they fear it and fail to understand its origin. In your travels, you will encounter witches and other sorcerers who are persecuted, tried, and put to the flames for their actions. It is time for you to play your role in what you can do to make those understand that magic is like a word; it can speak the truth and do good, yet it can also deceive and cause destruction. Level P. You learn additional Magi cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Magi table. Spell Slots he Magi table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your Magi spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a spell's level or higher slot, and you regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest. You know four 1st-level spells of your choice from the Magi spell list. The Spells Known column of the Magi table shows when you learn more Magi spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level. Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose up to two of the Magi spells you know and replace them with other spells from the Magi spell list; they also must be of a level for which you have spell slots. Spellcasting Ability Your spellcasting ability as a Maga / Magus is Your spellcasting ability as a Magi is Wisdom, reflecting your connection to your innate intuition and the mystical forces around you. Whenever a spell mentions your spellcasting ability, rely on your Wisdom. Furthermore, when determining the saving throw DC for your Delver of the Abyss spells or making an attack roll with them, apply your Charisma modifier. Here's how to calculate these values: Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier Level 1 Spirit Malady: Your knowledge of the mystical arts allows you to addle the mind or consume the body of those who seek to oppose you. Your spells, attacks or features granted by this class receive the following benefits: When you are about to deal poison damage to a target, you can choose to change the effect’s damage type to psychic or acid. When you are about to inflict the Poisoned condition, a creature immune to it can’t benefit from that immunity against this effect. When a creature is about to make a Constitution saving throw against an effect that inflicts poison damage (or psychic or acid, if the damage type has been changed with Spirit Malady) or the Poisoned condition, you can change the saving throw to an Intelligence one instead. Staff of the Elements: When you wield a quarterstaff, you can carry out one of the following: · Heal: As an Action, you can cure an ally within 15 ft. They can immediately spend one of their Hit Dice + their Constitution modifier; they regain that many hit points. · Protect: As a reaction when an ally within 30 ft. is about to be hit by an attack, you can cast a magical barrier to protect them. They gain a +2 bonus to their AC against the triggering attack, potentially causing it to miss. · Fulmen: As a bonus action, you can cast a noxious bolt up to 60 ft. Make a ranged spell attack against a creature within range; on a hit, the target takes 2d6 Poison Damage and they can’t take reactions until the start of their next turn. You can use your Staff of the Elements feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and you recover any expended usage when you complete a long rest. Studium: You gain proficiency in Insight. If you already have proficiency with that skill, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any Insight check you make. This feature does not stack with other bonuses that double your proficiency bonus for this skill. Level 2 Remedy Vial: You can distil a homebrewed liquid that grants whoever drinks it the benefit of one of these spells for 1 hour or until they end the effect: Comprehend Languages, Disguise Self, False Life (1st Level equivalent), Longstrider. You can prepare a number of these potions equal to your proficiency modifier while you take a Long Rest; they lose their effects when you take your next Long Rest. Nature’s Child: You have advantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks. You also gain resistance to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws against effects that inflict the Poisoned condition. Level 3 Viper’s Touch: whenever you deal poison (or psychic or acid, if the damage type has been changed with Spirit Malady) damage to a creature, they must succeed on a CON SAVE or become Poisoned until the end of your next turn. You can only affect creatures with a Challenge Rating equal to or lower than your level in this class with this feature. Amatorium: You have advantage on Charisma checks versus Beasts, Elementals, Feys and Plants; and you have advantage on Charisma saves against their spells and abilities. You gain the same benefits when dealing with humanoids and fiends, but only if they are Hags or Witches. Level 4 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 5 Spirit Contagion: whenever you deal poison (or psychic or acid, if the damage type has been changed with Spirit Malady) damage to a Poisoned creature, you can use your reaction to deal 1d6 poison damage to each creature of your choice within 5 ft. of the first one. Level 6 Empowered Staff: You recover any expended Staff of the Element usage when you complete a short rest. Each power granted by that feature is improved: · Heal: When you use the Heal power, you add your Wisdom modifier to the amount healed. · Protect: The Protect effect bonus to AC becomes equal to your proficiency bonus. · Fulmen: You can target up to two creatures with this attack. Level 7 Augury: as long as you are not surprised, you can use your reaction when rolling initiative to change the initiative value of another creature that you can see within 60 ft. of you. You can change this value so that it is as high as the highest value among the creatures in the current combat, plus one. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. Level 8 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 9 Potent Vial: when you brew your Remedy Vial, you can choose from these spells as well: Enhance Ability (2nd level equivalent), Darkvision, Alter Self, Feign Death, Invisibility (2nd level equivalent), Nondetection, Pass Without Trace, See Invisibility. Level 10 Hexxen: While you take a Long Rest, you can dream about a specific humanoid creature (IE: Thomas the Burgomaster) in your mind and cast a hex on them. After you complete your Long Rest, the creature has Disadvantage on rolls for checks or attacks that target only you. The effect lasts until you complete your next Long Rest. Nature’s Kin: You have advantage on saves against the effects of spells while you are in woods or other heavily forested environments. Level 11 Healer by Nature: You gain proficiency in Medicine. If you already have proficiency with that skill, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any Medicine check you make. This feature does not stack with other bonuses that double your proficiency bonus for this skill. Level 12 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 13 Pythonyssa: When a creature makes a save against your spells or effects that cause poison damage or the poisoned condition, they make the save with Disadvantage. Once a creature fails a save against one of these spells or effects, they can’t be affected by this feature again for the next 24 hours. Level 14 Repulse: As a reaction, when you take damage, you can expend a spell slot to reduce the damage by an amount equal to 1d8 per spell level. Once you use this feature you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. Level 15 Death's Door: When you or an ally within 30 feet of you drops to 0 hit points, as a reaction your magic connection to the afterlife allows you to restore them to life. They can immediately spend one of their Hit Dice + their Constitution modifier; they regain that many hit points, plus your Wisdom modifier. Once you use this feature you can't use it again until you finish a long rest. Level 16 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats). Level 17 Energized Staff: · Heal: You can target up to two creatures with this feature. · Protect: The effect lasts until the start of your next turn. · Fulmen: You can target a number of creatures equal to your proficiency bonus with this attack. Level 18 Blood Pact: Whenever you lose 20 hit points from a single source, as a reaction you can immediately cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action or less. Level 19 When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Alternatively, you can choose a feat (see PHB Chapter 6 for a list of feats) Level 20 AETHER WITCH You transform into a ghostly witch spirit and gain the following abilities: Poison Craft: You gain immunity to Poison damage and the Poisoned condition. Verhexen: attacks made against you with non magical means are made at Disadvantage. Etherealness: As an action, you can enter the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. You are visible on the Material Plane while you are in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet you can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane. Spirit: You gain a flying speed equal to your speed and you hover. You can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. You take 5 (1d10) force damage if you end your turn inside an object. Aetherial Grasp: As an action, you can extend your hand into the ethereal plane to manipulate or interact with objects on the material plane. This allows you to open doors, retrieve items, but you can’t attack or cast spells. name: Martyr
description: Squalid masses draw close around a young dwarf in spotless clothing. He touches each person in turn, healing injuries, curing illnesses, and restoring hope. A ragged tiefling speaks in a crowded square. As if in response, dark clouds gather over her head and the earth trembles at her words. A mad king spits and swears from his throne at imperial guards who have fled or been slain. A lone dragonborn stands before him, solemnly preparing herself for divinely demanded regicide. Martyrs are implements of the gods, hand-picked to spill their blood in service of a divine cause. Such an end is inevitable, for once a martyr is chosen, their fate is fixed in the heavens. Fated to Die Martyrs are chosen by the gods as prophets, oracles, great priests, and liberators. However, regardless of how much good they might accomplish in their lives, the end must always be the same: a glorious death, to be remembered in legend. No matter the circumstance, a martyr cannot avoid their destiny. While some martyrs gladly accept their holy approbation, others struggle against it. However, from the moment the gods choose their martyr, they shall intervene in the martyr’s fate, pulling them inexorably toward their cause. The gods will settle for a lesser martyr if they must—if the one chosen dies too soon—but they always prefer to uplift their martyr to the heights of sainthood before their inevitable demise. Blood of the Martyr Martyrs grow more powerful the closer they are to death, and those that spill their own blood evoke waves of divine energy. In the view of the gods, such hardship is necessary to lay the foundation for a story that will live on in history. Paradoxically, martyrs are protected from death’s precipice even as they are edged closer toward it. Every torment and persecution suffered by them is weighed with equal moments of respite offered by the gods. The gods do not mean to kill their charge early; a martyr should meet their fate only at the preordained time and place. Creating a Martyr As you create a martyr, think about the moment you were chosen by the gods and your burden was placed upon you. Were you visited by an angelic host or a god disguised as a mortal? Did you quietly hear a divine voice in your ear, as stigmata formed on your body? Was your soul violently dragged to the Upper (or Lower) Planes for an audience with the gods? Consider the life you led before you were ordained for martyrdom. Were you a wicked soul, purified and redeemed to undergo this task? Were you already a warrior, adventurer, or cleric in service of the gods? Also consider how you reacted. Did you accept the task and your inevitable destiny, or did you run from it? Are you still running? Quick Build To build a martyr quickly, follow these suggestions: Constitution should be your highest ability score. Your next highest ability score should be Strength if you choose a Burden, such as the Burden of Revolution, which focuses on melee combat, or Wisdom if you choose one focused on spellcasting. Choose any background. The Martyr Level Proficiency Bonus Features Max Spell Level Spell Uses 1st +2 Mortal Burden, Ordained Death — — 2nd +2 Spellcasting, Sainted Reprisal, Mark of the Herald 1st 2 3rd +2 Divine Healing, Torment 1st 3 4th +2 Ability Score Improvement 1st 3 5th +3 Extra Attack 2nd 6 6th +3 Mortal Burden feature 2nd 6 7th +3 Respite 2nd 7 8th +3 Ability Score Improvement 2nd 7 9th +4 — 3rd 9 10th +4 Undying Conviction 3rd 9 11th +4 Torment improvement 3rd 10 12th +4 Ability Score Improvement 3rd 10 13th +5 — 4th 11 14th +5 Mortal Burden feature 4th 11 15th +5 March Unto Destiny 4th 12 16th +5 Ability Score Improvement 4th 12 17th +6 — 5th 14 18th +6 Mortal Burden feature 5th 14 19th +6 Ability Score Improvement 5th 15 20th +6 Final Martyrdom 5th 15 Class Features As a martyr, you have the following class features. Hit Points Hit Dice: 1d12 per martyr level Hit Points at 1st Level: 12 + your Constitution modifier Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d12 (or 7) + your Constitution modifier per martyr level after 1st Proficiencies Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields Weapons: Simple and martial weapons Tools: None Saving Throws: Strength, Wisdom Skills: Choose two from Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Medicine, Persuasion, and Religion Equipment You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background: (a) a martial weapon and a shield or (b) two martial weapons (a) scale mail or (b) chain mail (if proficient) (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) any simple weapon (a) a priest’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack A holy symbol Mortal Burden Beginning at 1st level, you are fated to perish in the name of a great ideal, cementing your name alongside others who have done the same. Choose a Mortal Burden, detailed at the end of the class description. Your choice grants you features at 1st level, and again at 6th, 14th, and 18th level. Burden Spells Each burden has a list of associated spells that you gain at the martyr levels specified in the burden description. Once you gain access to a burden spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn’t count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain a burden spell that doesn’t appear on the martyr spell list, the spell is nonetheless a martyr spell for you. Ordained Death As a martyr, you have been predestined by the gods to perish for a great cause; there is no greater glory in death, and no greater joy in the afterlife. However, it is not yet your time. Starting at 1st level, when you fall to 0 hit points and begin to make death saving throws, you must fail 5 saving throws to die. Additionally, if a spell has the sole effect of restoring you to life (but not undeath), the caster doesn’t need material components to cast the spell on you. Mark of the Herald At 2nd level, your divine cause manifests itself upon you, forming a special mark or stigmata for all to see. You have advantage on ability checks you make to convince other creatures to assist you in service of your holy cause. Spellcasting Starting at 2nd level, you can leverage the power of your suffering to cast divine magic. Casting Spells To cast one of your martyr spells of 1st level or higher, you must lose hit points to create and expend a spell slot greater than or equal to that spell’s level. The number of hit points is listed on the Hit Points Spellcasting table and can’t be reduced or avoided. You don’t make Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration on spells as a result of losing these hit points. The Martyr table shows the maximum level of spell slot you can create. The Spell Uses column of the Martyr table shows how many spells you can cast. When you expend hit points to cast a spell, you expend one of these uses. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Hit Points Spellcasting Spell Level Point Cost 1st 5 2nd 10 3rd 20 4th 30 5th 45 Preparing Spells You prepare the list of martyr spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the martyr spell list. When you do so, choose a number of martyr spells equal to your Wisdom modifier + half your martyr level, rounded down (minimum of one spell). Spells you choose must be of a level no higher than what’s shown in the Max Spell Level column for your level. You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Healing Magic Because your power is derived from mortal suffering, you can’t regain hit points from any spell you cast. Spellcasting Ability Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your martyr spells, since your power originates in the devotion used to overcome your trials and tribulations. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a martyr spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one. Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier Spellcasting Focus You can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus for your martyr spells. Sainted Reprisal Also at 2nd level, you can reprimand those who draw your blood. When a creature you can see within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to deal 1d6 necrotic or radiant damage (your choice) to that creature. The damage increases by 1d6 when you reach 5th level (2d6), 11th level (3d6), and 17th level (4d6). Divine Healing Starting at 3rd level, you can utter a prayer to the gods for mercy. As an action, you can spend Hit Dice and regain hit points as if you had just finished a short rest. When you use this ability, you can spend a number of Hit Dice up to your proficiency bonus. Torment By 3rd level, you have learned to curry the gods’ favor through anguish and mortal trials. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can lose 5 hit points to deal an extra 10 necrotic or radiant damage (your choice) to the target. You don’t make Constitution saving throws to maintain concentration on spells as a result of losing these hit points. Starting at 11th level, you can choose to lose 10 hit points to deal an extra 20 damage to the target. Ability Score Improvement When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Extra Attack Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Respite Beginning at 7th level, you regain all expended Hit Dice when you finish a long rest, instead of only half of them. Undying Conviction Beginning at 10th level, when you drop to 0 hit points but aren’t killed outright, you can choose to drop to 1 hit point instead. Once you use this ability, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest. March Unto Destiny At 15th level, your inevitable end draws nearer, and nothing can hold you from it. You don’t need to eat or drink, and can’t be paralyzed, petrified, or stunned. Final Martyrdom At 20th level, you have at last reached your predestination: you will die in eternal glory. You can use your action to become immune to all damage for 10 minutes. For this duration, you can’t be blinded, charmed, deafened, exhausted, frightened, incapacitated, poisoned, restrained, or rendered unconscious. You have advantage on all ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws. Additionally, during this duration, you can cast the wish spell once, without expending a spell slot or hit points. If you use the spell to produce any effect other than duplicating another spell, the stress of casting it doesn’t reduce your Strength or cause you to take necrotic damage. At the end of this duration, you die. No force short of divine intervention can prevent your death, and you can’t be returned to life by any means. Mortal Burdens Martyrs are created and driven forth to right an inexorable wrong in the world. On this quest, they are a direct instrument of the gods, and no matter how hard they try, they cannot escape the burden of their duty. Mortal Burdens Name Description Burden of Atonement Aims to correct all the evils of their life through divine martyrdom Burden of Discord Spreads havoc and upsets the status quo Burden of the End One mission: prevent the end of the world Burden of Mercy Heals the sick and eases the suffering of all Burden of Rebirth Tasked with preserving the balance between civilization and the natural world Burden of Revolution Sent by the gods to spread freedom and crush despots Burden of Truth A prophet tasked with bringing a revolutionary truth to the world Burden of Tyranny Fated to become a king and rule with an iron fist

name: Melder
description: His palm extended, a dendus calls of a shimmer of frost to coalesce before him before unleashing its deadly cold toward his enemy. An lunar eldori weaves a micro-singularity—a black hole— which hovers over a nearby platform lifting and twisting all within its pull with a powerful crushing force. A utopian human touches an electrical port, extending her perceptions through the ship’s computer panels to gain an overview of the bridge nearby. Masters of matter and energy manipulation, melders have attuned themselves to the incredible raw power within the mysterious Crucibles. Using the energy within themselves, they are able to alter reality itself by combining, shaping and channeling the energies around them. It is an ability even the most learned of races still do not fully understand. Some espers wield their powers through use of sorium devices or implants. Melders know no such limitations. Their entire essence is infused with the power generated by the Crucibles, allowing them to draw matter and energy from around them and shape it to their desired form before releasing it. Weavers of the Cosmos Melders commune directly with the Crucibles in a system of codes and formula translated into controlled forms of energy. It is almost a language on its own, requiring a strong psyche to focus upon and comprehend as they “speak” with the forces around them. Once such a code is mastered it becomes part of the Melders repertoire of Talents. The most powerful of Melders view the forces of creation as one great cycle of energy, waiting to be tapped into. Channeling such massive surges of energy takes a toll on both the body and mind. It is almost as if they have two personas within them at the same time, each with a completely different train of thought. Once a Melder reaches their limit, they must recover their strength. If pushed further, they run the risk of both physical debilitation and possible descent into madness. Disciples of Infinity Due to their unique view of the connection between all things, a great many melders tend to try to look past the veil, striving to learn more about the nature of both their universe and the multiverse that exists beyond. Some believe that the Crucibles are merely a manifestation of realities and concepts that cannot yet be fathomed by the mortal mind, and that espers may be the key to their discovery. Creating a Melder When choosing Melder as your class, consider the event that took place in which your character was awakened to his or her abilities. Did something provoke this awakening? Perhaps they studied the practices of another melder? Maybe they were capable of strange feats at a young age, or encountered a strange creature or location where their powers manifested. Ability Scores Intelligence should be your primary ability score. Constitution could be considered secondary to supplement your hit points, followed by Wisdom and Charisma. Esper Talents At 1st level, you learn six talents of your choice which may be selected from the melder talents list. These represent the different methods you’ve learned in which you can shape matter and energy. Talent Points The Melder table shows the number of talent points you have to use on your esper talents. Each talent has a rank and a point cost associated with it. If you do not have enough points to cover the cost, you can’t use the talent. name: Monk
description: Her fists a blur as they deflect an incoming hail of arrows⁠, a half-elf springs over a barricade and throws herself into the massed ranks of hobgoblins on the other side. She whirls among them, knocking their blows aside and sending⁠ them reeling, until at last she stands alone. Taking a deep breath, a human covered in tattoos settles into a battle stance. As the first charging orcs reach him, he exhales and a blast of fire roars from his mouth, engulfing his foes. Moving with the silence⁠ of the night, a black-clad halfling steps into a shadow⁠ beneath an arch and emerges from another inky shadow⁠ on a balcony a stone’s throw away. She slides her blade free of its cloth-wrapped scabbard and peers through the open window at the tyrant prince, so vulnerable in the grip of sleep. Whatever their discipline, monks are united in their ability to magically harness the energy that flows in their bodies. Whether channeled as a striking display of combat⁠ prowess or a subtler focus of defensive ability and speed, this energy infuses all that a monk does. The Magic of Ki Monks make careful study of a magical energy that most monastic traditions call ki. This energy is an element of the magic that suffuses the multiverse—specifically, the element that flows through living bodies. Monks harness this power within themselves to create magical effects and exceed their bodies’ physical capabilities, and some of their special⁠ attacks can hinder the flow of ki in their opponents. Using this energy, monks channel uncanny speed and strength into their unarmed strikes. As they gain experience, their martial training and their mastery of ki gives them more power over their bodies and the bodies of their foes. Training and Asceticism Small walled cloisters dot the landscapes of the worlds of D&D, tiny refuges from the flow of ordinary life, where time seems to stand still. The monks who live there seek personal perfection through contemplation and rigorous training. Many entered the monastery as children, sent to live there when their parents died, when food couldn’t be found to support them, or in return for some kindness that the monks had performed for their families. Some monks live entirely apart from the surrounding population, secluded from anything that might impede their spiritual progress. Others are sworn to isolation, emerging only to serve as spies or assassins at the command⁠ of their leader, a noble patron, or some other mortal or divine power. The majority of monks don’t shun their neighbors, making frequent visits to nearby towns or villages and exchanging their service for food and other goods. As versatile⁠ warriors, monks often end up protecting their neighbors from monsters or tyrants. For a monk, becoming an adventurer means leaving a structured, communal lifestyle to become a wanderer. This can be a harsh transition, and monks don’t undertake it lightly. Those who leave their cloisters take their work seriously, approaching their adventures as personal tests of their physical and spiritual growth. As a rule, monks care little for material wealth and are driven by a desire to accomplish a greater mission than merely slaying monsters and plundering their treasure. Creating a Monk As you make your monk character, think about your connection to the monastery where you learned your skills and spent your formative years. Were you an orphan or a child left on the monastery’s threshold? Did your parents promise you to the monastery in gratitude for a service performed by the monks? Did you enter this secluded life to hide from a crime you committed? Or did you choose the monastic life for yourself? Consider why you left. Did the head of your monastery choose you for a particularly important mission beyond the cloister? Perhaps you were cast out because of some violation of the community’s rules. Did you dread leaving, or were you happy to go? Is there something you hope to accomplish outside the monastery? Are you eager to return to your home? As a result of the structured life of a monastic community and the discipline required to harness ki, monks are almost always lawful in alignment. Quick Build You can make a monk quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score, followed by Wisdom. Second, choose the hermit background. Hit Points Hit Dice: 1d8 per monk level Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per monk level after 1st Proficiencies Armor: None Weapons: Simple weapons, shortswords Tools: Choose one type of artisan’s tools or one musical instrument Saving Throws: Strength, Dexterity Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Athletics, History, Insight, Religion, and Stealth Equipment You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment⁠ granted by your background: ( a ) a shortsword or ( b ) any simple weapon ( a ) a dungeoneer’s pack or ( b ) an explorer’s pack 10 darts Unarmored Defense Beginning at 1st level, while you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier. Martial Arts At 1st level, your practice of martial arts gives you mastery of combat styles that use unarmed strikes and monk weapons, which are shortswords and any simple melee weapons⁠ that don’t have the two-handed or heavy property. You gain the following benefits while you are unarmed or wielding only monk weapons and you aren’t wearing armor or wielding a shield: You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes and monk weapons. You can roll a d4 in place of the normal damage of your unarmed strike or monk weapon. This die changes as you gain monk levels, as shown in the Martial Arts column of the Monk table. When you use the Attack action with an unarmed strike or a monk weapon on your turn, you can make one unarmed strike as a bonus action. For example, if you take the Attack action and attack with a quarterstaff, you can also make an unarmed strike as a bonus action, assuming you haven’t already taken a bonus action this turn. Certain monasteries use specialized forms of the monk weapons. For example, you might use a club that is two lengths of wood connected by a short chain (called a nunchaku) or a sickle with a shorter, straighter blade (called a kama). Whatever name you use for a monk weapon, you can use the game statistics provided for the weapon. Ki Starting at 2nd level, your training allows you to harness the mystic energy of ki. Your access to this energy is represented by a number of ki points. Your monk level determines the number of points you have, as shown in the Ki Points column of the Monk table. You can spend these points to fuel various ki features. You start knowing three such features: Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind. You learn more ki features as you gain levels in this class. When you spend a ki point, it is unavailable until you finish a short or long rest, at the end of which you draw all of your expended ki back into yourself. You must spend at least 30 minutes of the rest meditating to regain your ki points. Some of your ki features require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature’s effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows: Ki save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier Flurry of Blows Immediately after you take the Attack action on your turn, you can spend 1 ki point to make two unarmed strikes as a bonus action. Patient Defense You can spend 1 ki point to take the Dodge action as a bonus action on your turn. Step of the Wind You can spend 1 ki point to take the Disengage or Dash action as a bonus action on your turn, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn. Unarmored Movement⁠ Starting at 2nd level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield. This bonus increases when you reach certain monk levels, as shown in the Monk table. At 9th level, you gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move. Monastic Tradition When you reach 3rd level, you commit yourself to a monastic tradition: the Way of the Open Hand, the Way of Shadow, or the Way of the Four Elements, all detailed at the end of the class description. Your tradition grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 11th, and 17th level. Deflect Missiles Starting at 3rd level, you can use your reaction to deflect or catch the missile when you are hit by a ranged weapon attack. When you do so, the damage you take from the att⁠ack is reduced by 1d10 + your Dexterity modifier + your monk level. If you reduce the damage to 0, you can catch the missile if it is small enough for you to hold in one hand and you have at least one hand free. If you catch a missile in this way, you can spend 1 ki point to make a ranged att⁠ack with the weapon or piece of ammunition you just caught, as part of the same reaction. You make this atta⁠ck with proficiency, regardless of your weapon proficiencies, and the missile counts as a monk weapon for the att⁠ack. Ability Score Improvement When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature. Slow Fall Beginning at 4th level, you can use your reaction when you fall to reduce any falling damage you take by an amount equal to five times your monk level. Extra Attack Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Stunning Strike Starting at 5th level, you can interfere with the flow of ki in an opponent’s body. When you hit another creature with a melee weapon attack, you can spend 1 ki point to attempt a stunning strike. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be stunned until the end of your next turn. Ki-Empowered Strikes Starting at 6th level, your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. Evasion At 7th level, your instinctive agility lets you dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a blue dragon’s lightning breath or a fireball spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail. Stillness of Mind Starting at 7th level, you can use your action to end one effect on yourself that is causing you to be charmed or frightened. Purity of Body At 10th level, your mastery of the ki flowing through you makes you immune to disease and poison. Tongue of the Sun and Moon Starting at 13th level, you learn to touch the ki of other minds so that you understand all spoken languages. Moreover, any creature that can understand a language can understand what you say. Diamond Soul Beginning at 14th level, your mastery of ki grants you proficiency in all saving throws. Additionally, whenever you make a saving throw and fail, you can spend 1 ki point to reroll it and take the second result. Timeless Body At 15th level, your ki sustains you so that you suffer none of the frailty of old age, and you can’t be aged magically. You can still die of old age, however. In addition, you no longer need food or water. Empty Body Beginning at 18th level, you can use your action to spend 4 ki points to become invisible for 1 minute. During that time, you also have resistance to all damage but force damage. Additionally, you can spend 8 ki points to cast the astral projection spell, without needing material components. When you do so, you can’t take any other creatures with you. Perfect Self At 20th level, when you roll for initiative and have no ki points remaining, you regain 4 ki points. Monastic Orders The worlds of D&D contain a multitude of monasteries and monastic traditions. In lands with an Asian cultural flavor, such as Shou Lung far to the east of the Forgotten Realms, these monasteries are associated with philosophical traditions and martial arts practice. The Iron Hand School, the Five Stars School, the Northern Fist School, and the Southern Star School of Shou Lung teach different approaches to the physical, mental, and spiritual disciplines of the monk. Some of these monasteries have spread to the western lands of Faerûn, particularly in places with large Shou immigrant communities, such as Thesk and Westgate. Other monastic traditions are associated with deities who teach the value of physical excellence and mental discipline. In the Forgotten Realms, the order of the Dark Moon is made up of monks dedicated to Shar (goddess of loss), who maintain secret communities in remote hills, back allies, and subterranean hideaways. Monasteries of Ilmater (god of endurance) are named after flowers, and their orders carry the names of great heroes of the faith; the Disciples of Saint Sollars the Twice-Martyred reside in the Monastery of the Yellow Rose near Damara. The monasteries of Eberron combine the study of martial arts with a life of scholarship. Most are devoted to the deities of the Sovereign Host. In the world of Dragonlance, most monks are devoted to Majere, god of meditation and thought. In Greyhawk, many monasteries are dedicated to Xan Yae, the goddess of twilight and the superiority of mind over matter, or to Zuoken, god of mental and physical mastery. The evil monks of the Scarlet Brotherhood in the world of Greyhawk derive their fanatic zeal not from devotion to a god but from dedication to the principles of their nation and their race—the belief that the Suel strand of humanity are meant to rule the world. Monastic Traditions Three traditions of monastic pursuit are common⁠ in the monasteries scattered across the multiverse. Most monasteries practice one tradition exclusively, but a few honor the three traditions and instruct each monk according to his or her aptitude and interest. All three traditions rely on the same basic techniques, diverging as the student grows more adept. Thus, a monk need choose a tradition only upon reaching 3rd level.
